sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: This is Euronews Tonight. Here are your top stories.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Vladimir Putin scraps plans to storm the Azov steel plant in Mariupol, instead ordering a blockade.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The Russian president claims his country's forces have now taken control of the besieged port city.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Fighting continues in the east of Ukraine. The local governor of Luhansk says that 80% of the region is now in Russian hands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Russia finally takes action against US tech giant Google over Ukraine war content.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: We'll have the story.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And with just three days to go until the final round of the French presidential election, Macron and Le Pen caught those final undecided voters.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I'm Helena Humphrey. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russian President Vladimir Putin says he has ordered his troops not to storm the Azovstal steelwork plant in Mariupol, the last bastion of Ukrainian resistance in the besieged port city.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: During a meeting at the Kremlin, Russia's Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu told Putin that Mariupol had been quote-unquote liberated, but the thousands of Ukrainian troops remained holed up in its tunnels and basements below the steelworks. Russia is thought to have suffered significant losses in and around that facility as Ukrainian forces hold the strategic advantage in the network of underground passageways.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Russia's leader described a plan to seize the plant as impractical and instead called on his forces to blockade the area.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: I consider the proposed storming of the industrial area pointless. I order to abort it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: This is the case when we must think. That is, we must always think, but even more so in this case, about preserving the life and health of our soldiers and officers.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: There is no need to climb into these catacombs and crawl underground through these industrial facilities, block off this industrial area so that not even a fly comes through.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: block off this industrial area so that not even a fly comes through.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, Ukrainian officials have called for the opening of more humanitarian corridors to evacuate civilians still trapped inside Mariupol. Another three buses of evacuees from the port city arrived in Zaporizhia today after four buses did manage to leave on Wednesday with around 80 people.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But more than 100,000 people still remain and they're believed to have little or no food, water or medicines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: It comes as the latest figures from the UN Refugee Agency says that more than 600,000 additional people have been internally displaced since Sunday alone, totalling 7.7 million since the beginning of the invasion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: With me here in the studio bringing us up to date as ever with the latest developments

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: is our correspondent Sasha Vakulina.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Sasha, we heard that order from the Russian president Vladimir Putin saying don't storm the Azov steel plant but instead essentially blockade it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So for the people still hold up there, for the people on the ground, what does this mean in practical terms now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: They mean that they're as besieged as they were before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And when Vladimir Putin said not to storm Azovstal, he responded also to the comments from his defence minister, who said that it would still take several more days for the Russians to defeat the Ukrainians fighting at the steelworks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Not storming Azovstal now and blockading it as it is now but it's not about being pointless or impractical russian forces have been trying to defeat ukrainian fighters there for weeks ever since they took over mariupol which was early march it's been weeks and weeks kiev and western analysts they say that's because what we see now, the statements from Moscow follow the fact that they could not take over Azovstal by force.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This is why they're trying to blockade it now, to block everybody who is inside.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We do know about those tunnels and the basements and the shelters of the Azovstal.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Not only fighters are there, there are civilians, as you said, there are children, there are elderly people there there and also not storming Azovstal does not mean not shelling it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: There's been heavy shelling here this afternoon according to the administration of Mariupol with up to 80 people who managed to evacuate yesterday over 120,000, this is the latest information by Zelensky, civilians are still in Mariupol and as they they're staying there, they're not going to have any possibility now to evacuate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: They can't even try to break through evacuation corridors with their own vehicles, with their own cars.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And on top of that, Moscow and pro-Russian separatists in eastern Ukraine said that they do plan to have a Victory Day parade in Mariupol on the 9th of May this is the city that saw some of the heaviest fighting the city where more than 95 percent of everything all buildings now destroyed we still don't even know the full extent of the damage actually in Mariupol because obviously people haven't necessarily been able to get inside meanwhile and the rest of the country specifically in the east fighting continues there we heard some comments from the governor of Luhansk, who said that around 80% of that region is now in Russian hands. And when you hear that, that really does sound like a very rapid Russian advance. But of course, some of that ground was already controlled, as I understand it, due to the war there for the past eight years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: That's it. Some of the territory was already under the control of pro-russia separatists since 2014 since that invasion the beginning and as of now we do know that russians do continue their offensive operations claiming some suburbs of severa donetsk these are not big cities these are not big towns yes they try they push they try to advance further into the territory but they can't really now take make a major advances there in the east another place where there's been really struggling under very heavy bombardment is kharkiv that's northeast of ukraine now kharkiv ukraine's second largest city has been under non-stop bombardment with all systems and the civilians just trying to stay in shelter um we also know that u.s president joe biden he's just announced another military package i think he's put around around $800 million worth of weapons on the table for Ukraine. What is inside it? Is it what Zelensky was asking for? Well, let's see. There are two significant things here. First of all, because this is a continued support by the United States of America. This is the second time he's announcing it within just days or weeks, right? And then secondly this is very significant because there is some heavy weaponry in that aid package. We do know there will be some howitzers artillery rounds tactical vehicles tactical drones. So this is exactly the weaponry that Zelensky has been asking for from his Western allies. Why. Because he said look for for example for places like Mariupol there are two ways of unblocking them one is the negotiating diplomacy and we've seen that this did not work until now and the other one is heavy fighting and for this heavy fighting there are Ukrainian soldiers there are forces but they do need heavy weapons they can fight with all right Sasha Vakulina as ever your insights your knowledge of course greatly appreciated Sasha you. Now in the UK MPs in Westminster

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: have backed the opposition's call for a Commons inquiry to establish whether Boris Johnson knowingly misled Parliament over lockdown parties. The Labour Party is accusing the PM of lying when he repeatedly claimed Covid rules had not been broken in Downing Street. The PM was subsequently issued a fine by the police for breaking lockdown restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: A debate on the motion went ahead after a last-minute decision by the Prime Minister's Conservative Party to abandon its attempts to block it.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, Boris Johnson himself was in India, taking time to sign a visitor book praising Mahatma Gandhi's record on truth.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, tracking this vote and its result for us

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: from Westminster is our reporter Taig Enright, he joins us from London. Taig, good to see you. Talk us through this vote, its result and how it all unfolded.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Hi Helena, well this was effectively a game of political chess between the opposition and the government and Downing Street did not show itself as having the skills of a grand master. This opposition motion to try and get Parliament to investigate whether Boris Johnson misled it. The government initially tried to whip its own MPs, its Conservative MPs, to oppose it no matter what blowback they might have received from their constituents.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: They then sought to amend the motion to effectively neuter it, but then ultimately abandoned that plan as well, fearful of the optics of a rebellion by their own MPs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And as you say, in the end, it didn't even have to go to a vote.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It is parliamentary procedure here that if nobody actually voices opposition, screams out no when a motion is presented to the Parliament, then it simply waves through and that is what happened. Indeed, many Conservative MPs simply left Parliament for the week and headed back to their constituencies, avoiding the vote altogether. And I think one of the things that we learned today is that while Conservative MPs have been remarkably quiet, much quieter now, or in the last week since Boris Johnson got that fine for attending one of these lockdown parties, much quieter than when this scandal reached its climax back in January, there is a lot of anger there and you don't have to scratch the surface too much to reveal it. We heard a lot of new voices in the debate today criticizing the Prime Minister, including one very prominent MP on the right wing of the party, a chap called Steve Baker, who told him that the gig is up and that it is time for Boris Johnson to go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: AMNA NAWAZ It's certainly interesting to see what happens when the Prime Minister is out of the country, currently in India right now. And, Tai, what does all of this mean for the stability of the Prime Minister's position in office?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, what the vote, or lack there vote, the motion today means is that there will now be an inquiry by a parliamentary committee, i.e. other members of Parliament, into whether Boris Johnson misled Parliament or effectively lied to Parliament when he told them that he believed no lockdown rules were broken when all these parties were happening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And it further delays the final outcome of this whole Partygate scandal because not only have we had the civil service investigation to the parties, that is now finished, although not published.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We also have the police, the criminal investigation, which remains underway. Boris Johnson and his Chancellor have each received one fine. There could yet be more fines to come. But now we have this parliamentary investigation as to whether he lied about it. And that in itself won't begin until after the police have completed their investigation. So it's all going to be hanging over him for much longer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And this all assumes, though, that he will remain in office because, as I was saying there, there is growing evidence of the anger among Conservative MPs coming to the surface.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: His position is undoubtedly weakened by this motion.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And we are still, of course, waiting to see how voters will react when they go to the polls in council elections here in a few weeks' time.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Helena?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: All right, our reporter there, Tige Enright, on a sunny day outside of Westminster in London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Tige, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, staying in the UK and Britain's Queen Elizabeth II has turned 96 years old.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: The monarch's birthday comes ahead of her platinum jubilee celebrations in June, as our reporter Luke Hanrahan now reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: An official photograph to mark Elizabeth II's 96th birthday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Now in her 70th year as the monarch of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, head of the Commonwealth, defender of the faith.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: She invigorates that sense of natural British optimism.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I think there's that sense of tradition and longevity.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: It's almost inconceivable for the British people to imagine a time when Queen Elizabeth hasn't been their queen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: for the British people to imagine a time when Queen Elizabeth hasn't been their queen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: But the Queen in recent months has been replaced by her son Prince Charles at official engagements. Some have even suggested he's now Prince Regent in all but name, a king in waiting with increasing power, leaving the British public, perhaps for the first time, pondering life without Elizabeth in charge.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: I can't conceive it really, it's kind of, yeah, I don't know, I can't even put it into words, I can't imagine living here without her, because it's all we've ever known, isn't it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: I think people just don't want to think about it, do they? What's going to happen? One thing I always think is weird is having to change the national anthem to God Save the King, because I've obviously never sung that before.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: We've never known any different, and you've always just seen Charles as someone else that's there and you've never really thought of him as well. I personally never thought of him as becoming the king. For many in this country the big question is what happens next? There aren't that many people alive who can remember a time before Queen Elizabeth II. Not many know the answer and when Elizabeth became Queen the transition was quick.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: In the summer of 1951, the health of Elizabeth's father, King George VI, entered into a serious decline.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Just a few months later, at the age of just 25, Elizabeth became queen.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: It's not surprising that 70 years on the throne, that she is delegating some of the more mundane functions of the sovereign.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_11
sentences.sentence: People need to understand the constitutional structure that comes into play and how it operates and, you know, have some clarity about the schemes of delegation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: At 96 years old, the Queen continues to be the head of state, though the transition of responsibility is now underway.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_12
sentences.sentence: Luke Hanrahan, Euronews, London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, still to come, violence in Gaza intensifies as clashes in Jerusalem resume.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We'll be bringing you up to date with the situation after the break.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Welcome back. Thanks for joining me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: With just days to go until the second round of the French presidential election, Emmanuel Macron and rival Marine Le Pen have set their sights on left-wing voters in a final bid to come out on top.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now, after Wednesday night's TV debate, the incumbent president was in Saint-Denis Denis where in the first round he fell behind hard left candidate Jean-Luc Mélenchon while polls suggest Macron has a 10% lead over Le Pen millions of voters while they are still undecided Marine Le Pen greeted supporters in the industrial eau de france region where she insisted that she has every chance of winning the election what I want to bring in our international correspondent now, Annelies Borges, who joins us from Paris.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Annelies, good to see you.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: I guess voters have had a day now to digest that TV debate now that it's done and dusted.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Who came out on top? What are people making of it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, according to the polls earlier this morning, a vast majority of the French believed that Emmanuel Macron was the winner, if you will, of this debate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Fifty-nine percent of the respondents thought that he was more concise, clearer than his rival Marine Le Pen, who did do a good job for most respondents as well.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: She was significantly better prepared than five years ago.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: She was more composed as well and clearer on most of the topics that they touched.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Her team was actually claiming victory earlier today, saying that she was clearly stronger than Emmanuel Macron.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But what is clear, Helena, is that both candidates touched a wide range of issues during three hours of discussions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: They talked about the economy, about inflation and employment, but also about Europe, about climate change. So it was a very, very interesting exercise and one that required a lot of stamina from both of the candidates.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Emmanuel Macron accusing Marine Le Pen of being dependent on Russia and she, in exchange, said that he was a climate hypocrite.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But perhaps the most explosive clash of all of them was when they discussed immigration and integration and the place of the Islamic veil, the hijab, in public spaces here in France. Marine Le Pen, who wants to prohibit the use of the veil, and Emmanuel Macron accusing her of going against all the values of this country, but also of potentially pushing this country into a civil war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: So Annelies, you said they had that long debate last night. They needed a lot of stamina to get through it. But of course, no rest when you're on the campaign trail. Just a few days to go.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: They're continuing the charm offensive. How are they trying to win over those last undecided voters?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: offensive. How are they trying to win over those last undecided voters?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Since the early hours of today, both candidates hit the road once again. Marine Le Pen traveled to the city of Arras, which is in the north of France, an area that is normally an area very comfortable for Marine Le Pen. Over the last few years. She gained quite a lot of votes in the Pas-de-Calais. But Arras is a pro-Macron island in the middle of this area, if you will. The French president came out first there in the first round of this election. So Marine Le Pen was there trying to convince some of those voters that she represents a good alternative to the five years that they have just spent under Emmanuel Macron.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: The French president went to the suburbs of Paris.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: He traveled to Saint-Denis, to the north of the French capital, an area that voted for Jean-Luc Mélenchon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: 60% of the ballots cast there went for the leader of the far left.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And Emmanuel Macron was there shaking hands, greeting people, but also listening to some of their grievances.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: He was also set to go inside a building and visit some of the precarious accommodations in that area.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: So both candidates really trying hard to appear as much as possible. Emmanuel Macron, later today, will be on another TV show. This time is not going to be a debate.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And we all expect it to last a little less than three hours. But he will respond to questions of journalists. And, of course, tomorrow, both candidates will be holding their very last rallies ahead of the second round of the vote on Sunday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: All right, our international correspondent there, Anneliese Borges, covering the last breaths of the French presidential election.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Anneliese, thanks a lot.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Well, tensions remain high in Israel after the National Air Force

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: and Palestinian fighters traded fire across the Gaza frontier on Thursday.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: And this comes as clashes erupted once again at Jerusalem's holy sites.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Jada Silva Marquez reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Israeli forces have responded to Palestinian militants firing volleys of rockets from Gaza towards Israel with airstrikes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's the biggest escalation since last year's 11-day war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Far-right Israeli lawmaker Itamar Ben-Gavir also took part in a march in Jerusalem.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: This is despite Prime Minister Naftali Bennett barring him from entering Muslim areas of Jerusalem's Old City and holding a rally as the prime minister tried to stem further violence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Police in Jerusalem blocked roads in an attempt to prevent the march by ultra-nationalist Israelis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: After some pushing and shoving, the marchers rallied near barricades they were put in place, waving flags, singing and chanting.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: A similar event nearly a year ago triggered an Israeli-Gaza war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Wednesday's confrontation is the fifth this month.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Far-right Israeli groups had announced plans to storm the Al-Aqsa in large numbers to mark Passover festivities this week.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_10
sentences.sentence: After the break, we'll be taking a look at the latest move by Russia to limit big tech

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: control amid the war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Google has been fined for failing to take down what the Kremlin calls extremist content on YouTube.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: That story in just a moment.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Welcome back. Good to have you with us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: In a decisive move, a court in Russia has fined Google for failing to remove what it calls extremist content related to the war in Ukraine. Our team in the Cube has more now.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Well Helena, nearly all Western social media sites have been blocked in Russia, namely Meta-owned Facebook and Instagram as well as Twitter.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: But one of those that remains is Google and it has now though been slapped with a fine, something that Russia has been threatening to do for months.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: According to Russian media, a court in Moscow has accused YouTube, the video-sharing platform, of failing to heed warnings from the Russian state media watchdog, and of allowing extremist content to spread on its platform.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This includes allegedly videos related to Russian war casualties, as well as the Ukrainian Nationalist Battalion Azov.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: YouTube and Google, its parent company, have now been fined a total of 11 million rubles, that's around 124,000 euros.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: This is the first decisive move that Russia has taken against Google after, for weeks now, accusing it of spreading so-called fake news about the war in Ukraine and of taking a very anti-Russian stance.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: YouTube specifically has been told that it has allowed content on its platform that promotes violence towards Russian military personnel.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: It was just last week that the Russian government said that Google had been playing a leading role in the information war.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Now neither Google nor YouTube have responded to this latest fine, but we know that the company has blocked access to Russian state media channels as well as the Russian parliament, the Duma. Since the start of the invasion of Ukraine, Google's actions have undoubtedly infuriated Moscow. And Helena, this latest fine issued by a Moscow court just shows that the online information tug of war between Moscow and US tech giants, well, that information war is likely to rumble on. As you say, Matthew, very much a pattern and a move we have been waiting for. Thank you so much. But we leave you with a no comment from Disneyland in Hong Kong, where the gates are reopening.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: It's overcome thousands of, well, very delighted fans after a lengthy closure during the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: Thanks for watching Euronews tonight.
